title: 3 Easy Ways to Share Your Internet Connection From iPhone

steps.title: On your iPhone, open the Settings app.
steps.content: On your iPhone, open the Settings app. This may be located in a folder labeled "Utilities". [1] X Research source Make sure to update your iPhone .

steps.title: Tap Cellular.
steps.content: Tap Cellular . This will be located underneath Bluetooth . [2] X Research source

steps.title: Toggle Cellular Data on.
steps.content: Toggle Cellular Data on. This will need to be enabled in order to turn on the wireless hotspot.

steps.title: Tap Set Up Personal Hotspot.
steps.content: Tap Set Up Personal Hotspot . This button only appears if you've never used the personal hotspot before. If you have used the personal hotspot before, you'll see Personal Hotspot . [3] X Research source After setting up your personal hotspot for the first time, the Personal Hotspot option will appear in the main Settings menu. If this is grayed-out or missing, your carrier may not support a personal hotspot or you may need to upgrade your data plan. For a list of carriers that support wireless hotspots, see this Apple support page .

steps.title: Tap Wi-Fi Password.
steps.content: Tap Wi-Fi Password .

steps.title: Enter a password and tap Done.
steps.content: Enter a password and tap Done . This is the password you'll need to use the Personal Hotspot. Your password must contain at least 8 characters. If you choose to change the password later, this will disconnect any users or devices using your Personal Hotspot.

steps.title: Toggle on Allow Others to Join.
steps.content: Toggle on Allow Others to Join . Directions will appear on the bottom of the screen. [4] X Research source

steps.title: On your Windows computer, click the Networks icon.
steps.content: On your Windows computer, click the Networks icon. You'll see this in the System Tray in the lower-right corner of the screen.

steps.title: Select your iPhone's wireless hotspot and click Connect.
steps.content: Select your iPhone's wireless hotspot and click Connect . The name of the network will be the name of your device. If you're using Windows 11, click the arrow next to your Wi-Fi connection, make sure Wi-Fi is enabled, and then click your hotspot. To change your iPhone's name, you can go to Settings → General → About → Name . Enter a device name, then tap Done .

steps.title: Enter the password for the network and click Next.
steps.content: Enter the password for the network and click Next . This is the password you created earlier on your iPhone. After connecting, your computer will be able to connect to the internet using your iPhone's Personal Hotspot.

steps.title: On your iPhone, open the Settings app.
steps.content: On your iPhone, open the Settings app. This may be located in a folder labeled "Utilities". This method requires pairing your device to Windows .

steps.title: Tap Cellular.
steps.content: Tap Cellular . This will be located underneath Bluetooth .

steps.title: Toggle Cellular Data on.
steps.content: Toggle Cellular Data on. Cellular data needs to be enabled to use Bluetooth internet sharing.

steps.title: Tap Set Up Personal Hotspot.
steps.content: Tap Set Up Personal Hotspot . This button only appears if you've never used the personal hotspot before. If you have used the personal hotspot before, you'll see Personal Hotspot . Once you set up your first hotspot, the Personal Hotspot option will become available in the main Settings menu.

steps.title: Toggle on Allow Others to Join.
steps.content: Toggle on Allow Others to Join . Directions will appear on the bottom of the screen.

steps.title: Tap the < button in the top-left twice.
steps.content: Tap the < button in the top-left twice. This will return you to Cellular , then Settings .

steps.title: Tap Bluetooth.
steps.content: Tap Bluetooth . [5] X Research source

steps.title: Toggle on Bluetooth.
steps.content: Toggle on Bluetooth . Your Bluetooth must be active on both devices.

steps.title: On your Windows computer, open "Bluetooth & other devices".
steps.content: On your Windows computer, open "Bluetooth & other devices". This is where you can manage your Bluetooth connections. You can find this menu by clicking the Start menu and typing Bluetooth . Click Bluetooth and other devices settings . A new window will open.

steps.title: Toggle on Bluetooth.
steps.content: Toggle on Bluetooth . You will see Now discoverable as "(device name)" underneath Bluetooth .

steps.title: Click Add Bluetooth or other device.
steps.content: Click Add Bluetooth or other device . This will be located at the very top of the window. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Click Bluetooth.
steps.content: Click Bluetooth . Your computer will begin searching for a discoverable device. If you don't see your iPhone, make sure to tap Allow new connections . If you don't see this option, make sure your iPhone is close to your computer.

steps.title: On your iPhone, tap your computer name.
steps.content: On your iPhone, tap your computer name. You can find this under Other Devices . Your devices may take a moment to connect. On your computer, a new window will appear with Pair device? at the top.

steps.title: Click Allow.
steps.content: Click Allow . You will see Connection succeeded in a new window. Click Close to close the window. On your iPhone, you should see Connected next to your computer name.

steps.title: Open the Control Panel.
steps.content: Open the Control Panel. You can find this by clicking the Start menu and typing in Control Panel . The icon looks like a graph and switches with a blue background.

steps.title: Click View devices and printers.
steps.content: Click View devices and printers . This can be found underneath Hardware and Sound . A new window will open. You'll see all your connected devices and printers.

steps.title: Right-click your iPhone.
steps.content: Right-click your iPhone. It should be located underneath Devices . A drop-down menu will open.

steps.title: Hover over Connect using, then click Access point.
steps.content: Hover over Connect using , then click Access point . Your Windows PC will now use your iPhone's internet connection over Bluetooth. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Install iTunes
steps.content: Install iTunes on your Windows computer. If you're tethering your iPhone to a Windows computer, the computer will need to have iTunes installed in order to connect.

steps.title: On your iPhone, open the Settings app.
steps.content: On your iPhone, open the Settings app. This may be located in a folder labeled "Utilities".

steps.title: Tap Cellular.
steps.content: Tap Cellular . This will be located underneath Bluetooth .

steps.title: Toggle on Cellular Data.
steps.content: Toggle on Cellular Data . Cellular data needs to be enabled to use Bluetooth internet sharing.

steps.title: Tap Set Up Personal Hotspot.
steps.content: Tap Set Up Personal Hotspot . This button only appears if you've never used the personal hotspot before. If you have used the personal hotspot before, you'll see Personal Hotspot . Once you set up your first hotspot, the Personal Hotspot option will become available in the main Settings menu.

steps.title: Toggle on Allow Others to Join.
steps.content: Toggle on Allow Others to Join . Directions will appear on the bottom of the screen.

steps.title: Plug your iPhone into your computer's USB port.
steps.content: Plug your iPhone into your computer's USB port. Depending on your iPhone, you may need an Apple Lightning to USB cable or Apple USB-C to USB cable. [8] X Research source Make sure your iPhone is unlocked. You may receive a prompt on your iPhone: Trust this computer? Tap Trust .

steps.title: Click the Network icon on your computer.
steps.content: Click the Network icon on your computer. In Windows, you'll find this in the System Tray, which is next to the clock.

steps.title: Click your iPhone to select it as your computer's network.
steps.content: Click your iPhone to select it as your computer's network. Your computer will now use your iPhone's internet connection as you browse the internet. [9] X Research source With your iPhone connected, you can also transfer photos to your PC or back up your device .
